column2: CHAPTER II: THE DYING WORLD
column3: CHAPTER two: THE DYING WORLD

column2: In the upper story of a house in the Museum Street of Alexandria, built and fitted up on the old Athenian model, was a small room.
column3: In the upper story of a house in the Museum Street of Alexandria, built and fitted up on the old Athenian model, was a small room.

column2: It had been chosen by its occupant, not merely on account of its quiet; for though it was tolerably out of hearing of the female slaves who worked, and chattered, and quarrelled under the cloisters of the women's court on the south side, yet it was exposed to the rattle of carriages and the voices of passengers in the fashionable street below, and to strange bursts of roaring, squealing, trumpeting from the Menagerie, a short way off, on the opposite side of the street.
column3: It had been chosen by its occupant, not merely on account of its quiet; for though it was tolerably out of hearing of the female slaves who worked, and chattered, and quarrelled under the cloisters of the women's court on the south side, yet it was exposed to the rattle of carriages and the voices of passengers in the fashionable street below, and to strange bursts of roaring, squealing, trumpeting from the Menagerie, a short way off, on the opposite side of the street.

column2: The attraction of the situation lay, perhaps, in the view which it commanded over the wall of the Museum gardens, of flower-beds, shrubberies, fountains, statues, walks, and alcoves, which had echoed for nearly seven hundred years to the wisdom of the Alexandrian sages and poets.
column3: The attraction of the situation lay, perhaps, in the view which it commanded over the wall of the Museum gardens, of flower beds, shrubberies, fountains, statues, walks, and alcoves, which had echoed for nearly seven hundred years to the wisdom of the Alexandrian sages and poets.

column2: School after school, they had all walked, and taught, and sung there, beneath the spreading planes and chestnuts, figs and palm-trees.
column3: School after school, they had all walked, and taught, and sung there, beneath the spreading planes and chestnuts, figs and palm trees.

column2: The place seemed fragrant with all the riches of Greek thought and song, since the days when Ptolemy Philadelphus walked there with Euclid and Theocritus, Callimachus and Lycophron.
column3: The place seemed fragrant with all the riches of Greek thought and song, since the days when Ptolemy Philadelphus walked there with Euclid and Theocritus, Callimachus and Lycophron.

column2: On the left of the garden stretched the lofty eastern front of the Museum itself, with its picture galleries, halls of statuary, dining-halls, and lecture-rooms; one huge wing containing that famous library, founded by the father of Philadelphus, which hold in the time of Seneca, even after the destruction of a great part of it in Caesar's siege, four hundred thousand manuscripts.
column3: On the left of the garden stretched the lofty eastern front of the Museum itself, with its picture galleries, halls of statuary, dining halls, and lecture rooms; one huge wing containing that famous library, founded by the father of Philadelphus, which hold in the time of Seneca, even after the destruction of a great part of it in Caesar's siege, four hundred thousand manuscripts.

column2: There it towered up, the wonder of the world, its white roof bright against the rainless blue; and beyond it, among the ridges and pediments of noble buildings, a broad glimpse of the bright blue sea.
column3: There it towered up, the wonder of the world, its white roof bright against the rainless blue; and beyond it, among the ridges and pediments of noble buildings, a broad glimpse of the bright blue sea.

column2: The room was fitted up in the purest Greek style, not without an affectation of archaism, in the severe forms and subdued half-tints of the frescoes which ornamented the walls with scenes from the old myths of Athene.
column3: The room was fitted up in the purest Greek style, not without an affectation of archaism, in the severe forms and subdued half tints of the frescoes which ornamented the walls with scenes from the old myths of Athene.

column2: Yet the general effect, even under the blazing sun which poured in through the mosquito nets of the courtyard windows, was one of exquisite coolness, and cleanliness, and repose.
column3: Yet the general effect, even under the blazing sun which poured in through the mosquito nets of the courtyard windows, was one of exquisite coolness, and cleanliness, and repose.

column2: The room had neither carpet nor fireplace; and the only movables in it were a sofa-bed, a table, and an arm-chair, all of such delicate and graceful forms as may be seen on ancient vases of a far earlier period than that whereof we write.
column3: The room had neither carpet nor fireplace; and the only movables in it were a sofa bed, a table, and an arm chair, all of such delicate and graceful forms as may be seen on ancient vases of a far earlier period than that whereof we write.

column2: But, most probably, had any of us entered that room that morning, we should not have been able to spare a look either for the furniture, or the general effect, or the Museum gardens, or the sparkling Mediterranean beyond; but we should have agreed that the room was quite rich enough for human eyes, for the sake of one treasure which it possessed, and, beside which, nothing was worth a moment's glance.
column3: But, most probably, had any of us entered that room that morning, we should not have been able to spare a look either for the furniture, or the general effect, or the Museum gardens, or the sparkling Mediterranean beyond; but we should have agreed that the room was quite rich enough for human eyes, for the sake of one treasure which it possessed, and, beside which, nothing was worth a moment's glance.

column2: For in the light arm-chair, reading a manuscript which lay on the table, sat a woman, of some five-and-twenty years, evidently the tutelary goddess of that little shrine, dressed in perfect keeping with the archaism of the chamber, in simple old snow-white Ionic robe, falling to the feet and reaching to the throat, and of that peculiarly severe and graceful fashion in which the upper part of the dress falls downward again from the neck to the waist in a sort of cape, entirely hiding the outline of the bust, while it leaves the arms and the point of the shoulders bare. Her dress was entirely without ornament, except the two narrow purple stripes down the front, which marked her rank as a Roman citizen, the gold embroidered shoes upon her feet, and the gold net, which looped back, from her forehead to her neck, hair the colour and gloss of which were hardly distinguishable from that of the metal itself, such as Athene herself might heaven vied for tint, and mass, and ripple.
column3: For in the light arm chair, reading a manuscript which lay on the table, sat a woman, of some five and twenty years, evidently the tutelary goddess of that little shrine, dressed in perfect keeping with the archaism of the chamber, in simple old snow white Ionic robe, falling to the feet and reaching to the throat, and of that peculiarly severe and graceful fashion in which the upper part of the dress falls downward again from the neck to the waist in a sort of cape, entirely hiding the outline of the bust, while it leaves the arms and the point of the shoulders bare. Her dress was entirely without ornament, except the two narrow purple stripes down the front, which marked her rank as a Roman citizen, the gold embroidered shoes upon her feet, and the gold net, which looped back, from her forehead to her neck, hair the colour and gloss of which were hardly distinguishable from that of the metal itself, such as Athene herself might heaven vied for tint, and mass, and ripple.

column2: Her features, arms, and hands were of the severest and grandest type of old Greek beauty, at once showing everywhere the high development of the bones, and covering them with that firm, round, ripe outline, and waxy morbidezza of skin, which the old Greeks owed to their continual use not only of the bath and muscular exercise, but also of daily unguents. There might have seemed to us too much sadness in that clear gray eye; too much self-conscious restraint in those sharp curved lips; too much affectation in the studied severity of her posture as she read, copied, as it seemed, from some old vase or bas-relief.
column3: Her features, arms, and hands were of the severest and grandest type of old Greek beauty, at once showing everywhere the high development of the bones, and covering them with that firm, round, ripe outline, and waxy morbidezza of skin, which the old Greeks owed to their continual use not only of the bath and muscular exercise, but also of daily unguents. There might have seemed to us too much sadness in that clear gray eye; too much self conscious restraint in those sharp curved lips; too much affectation in the studied severity of her posture as she read, copied, as it seemed, from some old vase or bas relief.

column2: But the glorious grace and beauty of every line of face and figure would have excused, even hidden those defects, and we should have only recognised the marked resemblance to the ideal portraits of Athene which adorned every panel of the walls.
column3: But the glorious grace and beauty of every line of face and figure would have excused, even hidden those defects, and we should have only recognised the marked resemblance to the ideal portraits of Athene which adorned every panel of the walls.

column2: 'Yes.

column2: The statues there are broken.
column3: The statues there are broken.

column2: The libraries are plundered.
column3: The libraries are plundered.

column2: The alcoves are silent.
column3: The alcoves are silent.

column2: The oracles are dumb.
column3: The oracles are dumb.

column2: And yet--who says that the old faith of heroes and sages is dead?
column3: And yet-who says that the old faith of heroes and sages is dead?

column2: The beautiful can never die.
column3: The beautiful can never die.

column2: If the gods have deserted their oracles, they have not deserted the souls who aspire to them.
column3: If the gods have deserted their oracles, they have not deserted the souls who aspire to them.

column2: If they have ceased to guide nations, they have not ceased to speak to their own elect.
column3: If they have ceased to guide nations, they have not ceased to speak to their own elect.

column2: If they have cast off the vulgar herd, they have not cast off Hypatia. ...............
column3: If they have cast off the vulgar herd, they have not cast off Hypatia. ...............

column2: 'Ay.
column3: 'Ay.

column2: To believe in the old creeds, while every one else is dropping away from them....
column3: To believe in the old creeds, while every one else is dropping away from them....

column2: To believe in spite of disappointments....
column3: To believe in spite of disappointments....

column2: To hope against hope....
column3: To hope against hope....

column2: To show oneself superior to the herd, by seeing boundless depths of living glory in myths which have become dark and dead to them....
column3: To show oneself superior to the herd, by seeing boundless depths of living glory in myths which have become dark and dead to them....

column2: To struggle to the last against the new and vulgar superstitions of a rotting age, for the faith of my forefathers, for the old gods, the old heroes, the old sages who gauged the mysteries of heaven and earth--and perhaps to conquer--at least to have my reward! To be welcomed into the celestial ranks of the heroic--to rise to the immortal gods, to the ineffable powers, onward, upward ever, through ages and through eternities, till I find my home at last, and vanish in the glory of the Nameless and the Absolute One!....
column3: To struggle to the last against the new and vulgar superstitions of a rotting age, for the faith of my forefathers, for the old gods, the old heroes, the old sages who gauged the mysteries of heaven and earth-and perhaps to conquer-at least to have my reward! To be welcomed into the celestial ranks of the heroic-to rise to the immortal gods, to the ineffable powers, onward, upward ever, through ages and through eternities, till I find my home at last, and vanish in the glory of the Nameless and the Absolute One!....

column2: 'Not even between them; not even between philosophy and barbarism.
column3: 'Not even between them; not even between philosophy and barbarism.

column2: The struggle is simply one between the aristocracy and the mob,--between wealth, refinement, art, learning, all that makes a nation great, and the savage herd of child-breeders below, the many ignoble, who were meant to labour for the noble few.
column3: The struggle is simply one between the aristocracy and the mob,--between wealth, refinement, art, learning, all that makes a nation great, and the savage herd of child breeders below, the many ignoble, who were meant to labour for the noble few.

column2: Shall the Roman empire command or obey her own slaves? is the question which you and Cyril have to battle out; and the fight must be internecine.'
column3: Shall the Roman empire command or obey her own slaves? is the question which you and Cyril have to battle out; and the fight must be internecine.'

column2: 'I should not wonder if it became so, really,' answered the prefect, with a shrug of his shoulders.
column3: 'I should not wonder if it became so, really,' answered the prefect, with a shrug of his shoulders.

column2: 'I expect every time I ride, to have my brains knocked out by some mad monk.'
column3: 'I expect every time I ride, to have my brains knocked out by some mad monk.'

column2: 'Why not?
column3: 'Why not?

column2: In an age when, as has been well and often said, emperors and consulars crawl to the tombs of a tent-maker and a fisherman, and kiss the mouldy bones of the vilest slaves?
column3: In an age when, as has been well and often said, emperors and consulars crawl to the tombs of a tent maker and a fisherman, and kiss the mouldy bones of the vilest slaves?

column2: Why not, among a people whose God is the crucified son of a carpenter?
column3: Why not, among a people whose God is the crucified son of a carpenter?

column2: Why should learning, authority, antiquity, birth, rank, the system of empire which has been growing up, fed by the accumulated wisdom of ages,--why, I say, should any of these things protect your life a moment from the fury of any beggar who believes that the Son of God died for him as much as for you, and that he is your equal if not your superior in the sight of his low-born and illiterate deity!' [Footnote: These are the arguments and the language which were commonly employed by Porphyry, Julian, and the other opponents of Christianity.]
column3: Why should learning, authority, antiquity, birth, rank, the system of empire which has been growing up, fed by the accumulated wisdom of ages,--why, I say, should any of these things protect your life a moment from the fury of any beggar who believes that the Son of God died for him as much as for you, and that he is your equal if not your superior in the sight of his low born and illiterate deity!' [Footnote: These are the arguments and the language which were commonly employed by Porphyry, Julian, and the other opponents of Christianity.]

column2: 'My most eloquent philosopher, this may be--and perhaps is--all very true.
column3: 'My most eloquent philosopher, this may be-and perhaps is-all very true.

column2: I quite agree that there are very great practical inconveniences of this kind in the new--I mean the Catholic faith; but the world is full of inconveniences.
column3: I quite agree that there are very great practical inconveniences of this kind in the new-I mean the Catholic faith; but the world is full of inconveniences.

column2: The wise man does not quarrel with his creed for being disagreeable, any more than he does with his finger for aching: he cannot help it, and must make the best of a bad matter.
column3: The wise man does not quarrel with his creed for being disagreeable, any more than he does with his finger for aching: he cannot help it, and must make the best of a bad matter.

column2: Only tell me how to keep the peace.'
column3: Only tell me how to keep the peace.'

column2: 'And let philosophy be destroyed?'
column3: 'And let philosophy be destroyed?'

column2: 'That it never will be, as long as Hypatia lives to illuminate the earth; and, as far as I am concerned, I promise you a clear stage and--a great deal of favour; as is proved by my visiting you publicly at this moment, before I have given audience to one of the four hundred bores, great and small, who are waiting in the tribunal to torment me.
column3: 'That it never will be, as long as Hypatia lives to illuminate the earth; and, as far as I am concerned, I promise you a clear stage and-a great deal of favour; as is proved by my visiting you publicly at this moment, before I have given audience to one of the four hundred bores, great and small, who are waiting in the tribunal to torment me.

column2: Do help me and advise me.
column3: Do help me and advise me.

column2: What am I to do?'
column3: What am I to do?'

column2: 'I have told you.'
column3: 'I have told you.'

column2: 'Ah, yes, as to general principles.
column3: 'Ah, yes, as to general principles.

column2: But out of the lecture-room I prefer a practical expedient for instance, Cyril writes to me here--plague on him! he would not let me even have a week's hunting in peace-that there is a plot on the part of the Jews to murder all the Christians.
column3: But out of the lecture room I prefer a practical expedient for instance, Cyril writes to me here-plague on him! he would not let me even have a week's hunting in peace that there is a plot on the part of the Jews to murder all the Christians.

column2: Here is the precious document--do look at it, in pity.
column3: Here is the precious document-do look at it, in pity.

column2: For aught I know or care, the plot may be an exactly opposite one, and the Christians intend to murder all the Jews.
column3: For aught I know or care, the plot may be an exactly opposite one, and the Christians intend to murder all the Jews.

column2: But I must take some notice of the letter.'
column3: But I must take some notice of the letter.'

column2: 'I do not see that, your excellency.'
column3: 'I do not see that, your excellency.'

column2: 'Why, if anything did happen, after all, conceive the missives which would be sent flying off to Constantinople against me!'
column3: 'Why, if anything did happen, after all, conceive the missives which would be sent flying off to Constantinople against me!'

column2: 'Let them go.
column3: 'Let them go.

column2: If you are secure in the consciousness of innocence, what matter?'
column3: If you are secure in the consciousness of innocence, what matter?'

column2: 'Consciousness of innocence?
column3: 'Consciousness of innocence?

column2: I shall lose my prefecture!'
column3: I shall lose my prefecture!'

column2: 'Your danger would just be as great if you took notice of it.
column3: 'Your danger would just be as great if you took notice of it.

column2: Whatever happened, you would be accused of favouring the Jews.'
column3: Whatever happened, you would be accused of favouring the Jews.'

column2: 'And really there might be some truth in the accusation.
column3: 'And really there might be some truth in the accusation.

column2: How the finances of the provinces would go on without their kind assistance, I dare not think.
column3: How the finances of the provinces would go on without their kind assistance, I dare not think.

column2: If those Christians would but lend me their money, instead of building alms-houses and hospitals with it, they might burn the Jews' quarter to-morrow, for aught I care.
column3: If those Christians would but lend me their money, instead of building alms houses and hospitals with it, they might burn the Jews' quarter to morrow, for aught I care.

column2: But now....'
column3: But now....'

column2: 'But now, you must absolutely take no notice of this letter.
column3: 'But now, you must absolutely take no notice of this letter.

column2: The very tone of it forbids you, for your own honour, and the honour of the empire.
column3: The very tone of it forbids you, for your own honour, and the honour of the empire.

column2: Are you to treat with a man who talks of the masses at Alexandria as "the flock whom the King of kings has committed to his rule and care"?
column3: Are you to treat with a man who talks of the masses at Alexandria as "the flock whom the King of kings has committed to his rule and care"?

column2: Does your excellency, or this proud bishop, govern Alexandria?'
column3: Does your excellency, or this proud bishop, govern Alexandria?'

column2: 'Really, my dear lady, I have given up inquiring.'
column3: 'Really, my dear lady, I have given up inquiring.'

column2: 'But he has not.
column3: 'But he has not.

column2: He comes to you as a person possessing an absolute authority over two-thirds of the population, which he does not scruple to hint to you is derived from a higher source than your own.
column3: He comes to you as a person possessing an absolute authority over two thirds of the population, which he does not scruple to hint to you is derived from a higher source than your own.

column2: The consequence is clear.
column3: The consequence is clear.

column2: If it be from a higher source than yours, of course it ought to control yours'; and you will confess that it ought to control it--you will acknowledge the root and ground of every extravagant claim which he makes, if you deign to reply.'
column3: If it be from a higher source than yours, of course it ought to control yours'; and you will confess that it ought to control it-you will acknowledge the root and ground of every extravagant claim which he makes, if you deign to reply.'

column2: 'But I must say something, or I shall be pelted in the streets.
column3: 'But I must say something, or I shall be pelted in the streets.

column2: You philosophers, however raised above your own bodies you may be, must really not forget that we poor worldlings have bones to be broken.'
column3: You philosophers, however raised above your own bodies you may be, must really not forget that we poor worldlings have bones to be broken.'

column2: 'Then tell him, and by word of mouth merely, that as the information which he sends you comes from his private knowledge and concerns not him as bishop, but you as magistrate, you can only take it into consideration when he addresses you as a private person, laying a regular information at your tribunal.'
column3: 'Then tell him, and by word of mouth merely, that as the information which he sends you comes from his private knowledge and concerns not him as bishop, but you as magistrate, you can only take it into consideration when he addresses you as a private person, laying a regular information at your tribunal.'

column2: 'Charming! queen of diplomatists as well as philosophers!
column3: 'Charming! queen of diplomatists as well as philosophers!

column2: I go to obey you.
column3: I go to obey you.

column2: Ah! why were you not Pulcheria?
column3: Ah! why were you not Pulcheria?

column2: No, for then Alexandria had been dark, and Orestes missed the supreme happiness of kissing a hand which Pallas, when she made you, must have borrowed from the workshop of Aphrodite.'
column3: No, for then Alexandria had been dark, and Orestes missed the supreme happiness of kissing a hand which Pallas, when she made you, must have borrowed from the workshop of Aphrodite.'

column2: 'Recollect that you are a Christian,' answered Hypatia, half smiling.
column3: 'Recollect that you are a Christian,' answered Hypatia, half smiling.

column2: So the prefect departed; and passing through the outer hall, which was already crowded with Hypatia's aristocratic pupils and visitors, bowed his way out past them and regained his chariot, chuckling over the rebuff which he intended to administer to Cyril, and comforting himself with the only text of Scripture of the inspiration of which he was thoroughly convinced--'Sufficient for the day is the evil thereof.'
column3: So the prefect departed; and passing through the outer hall, which was already crowded with Hypatia's aristocratic pupils and visitors, bowed his way out past them and regained his chariot, chuckling over the rebuff which he intended to administer to Cyril, and comforting himself with the only text of Scripture of the inspiration of which he was thoroughly convinced-'Sufficient for the day is the evil thereof.'

column2: At the door was a crowd of chariots, slaves with their masters' parasols, and the rabble of onlooking boys and market-folk, as usual in Alexandria then, as in all great cities since, who were staring at the prefect, and having their heads rapped by his guards, and wondering what sort of glorious personage Hypatia might be, and what sort of glorious house she must live in, to be fit company for the great governor of Alexandria.
column3: At the door was a crowd of chariots, slaves with their masters' parasols, and the rabble of onlooking boys and market folk, as usual in Alexandria then, as in all great cities since, who were staring at the prefect, and having their heads rapped by his guards, and wondering what sort of glorious personage Hypatia might be, and what sort of glorious house she must live in, to be fit company for the great governor of Alexandria.

column2: Not that there was not many a sulky and lowering face among the mob, for the great majority of them were Christians, and very seditious and turbulent politicians, as Alexandrians, 'men of Macedonia,' were bound to be; and there was many a grumble among them, all but audible, at the prefect's going in state to the heathen woman's house--heathen sorceress, some pious old woman called her--before he heard any poor soul's petition in the tribunal, or even said his prayers in church.
column3: Not that there was not many a sulky and lowering face among the mob, for the great majority of them were Christians, and very seditious and turbulent politicians, as Alexandrians, 'men of Macedonia,' were bound to be; and there was many a grumble among them, all but audible, at the prefect's going in state to the heathen woman's house-heathen sorceress, some pious old woman called her-before he heard any poor soul's petition in the tribunal, or even said his prayers in church.
